physDesc.p: This letter is five pages long. The word Aldington is written in pencil in the top left at a forty-five-degree angle slanting upwards from left to right. The date is in the top right along with the page annotation from the second page on (R.A.–[Page #]).

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: It was perfectly delightful to have a letter from you again. It is so long since I have heard from you direct, but Hilda is a brick and writes often and keeps me up with things. This war has meant to me an exile from some of the people I care for most and from the only people whose work I sincerely and unequivocally admire, but that is very little a sacrifice to make considering how many more terrible ones other people have to undergo.

What you say about keeping alive the tradition des libres esprits interests me very much. I have worried considerably about my part in this war. I have such rotten health that there has been no use in thinking of going to France or doing anything active. I had a very unpleasant illness last year, as you know, that pretty nearly wiped me off the face of the earth, and although I am very much better, I have almost no endurance physically, and to make things more amusing my eyes have given out, and it is with the greatest difficulty that I can get through the work I have to do. You would laugh to see me; I am be-spectacled like a German. All this does not matter, of course, except that it seemed almost impossible to do my bit, but I have at last come to the comforting conclusion that there is a bit to be done in merely keeping alive the spirit of civilization through the only medium I know – that of poetry.

For us women who cannot fight, and who are handicapped in other ways from taking any active part, I feel that the truest thing we can possibly do is just this, and I must say I have been happier since I have come to the conclusion. We must keep a world going for the rest of you when you come back. We must keep alive the spirit of beauty, of gentleness, and of idealism. It may be that the war will go on so long that these things will perish perforce for a time, but the whole strength of my mind is now turned towards poetry – not that it always was not so, but the thing has taken on a higher meaning and a greater reality, if that were possible, and I think that when you come back from the army, the world you will have to work in will be more inclined to listen than it ever was before. At least that seems to be coming to be true of America, and I have the gratifying sense of realizing that my efforts on behalf of poetry in this country are beginning to bear fruit at last. I do not at all share with the “Little Review’s” attitude of “Rough Men.” I have never dwelt in an ivory tower, nor found it possible to divorce myself from the facts of life. I think there is a great deal more poetry in these sort of people than one realizes, although, of course, it is largely an untrained taste. Here we have had a most curious experience. Each of the training camps has a library, and they tell me that the demand for poetry in these libraries is phenomenal. Of course the kind of poetry is not always what you and I would choose, for they like Kipling and Robert Service as well as a lot of other things, but that a lot of private soldiers that come from every walk in life should loudly demand poetry is such an extraordinary thing that I cannot explain it except by thinking that this country is at last seeking for beauty and an expression of the other side of life. I do not think there has ever been a time when common soldiers have requested poetry, and the thing seems to me highly significant of the whole attitude which this country has towards the war.
Nobody can hate war worse than I do, but I believe in this war with my whole heart and soul, in the absolute necessity of it – melancholy though that is.

The Brookline Public Library has asked for donations of books to send to the various camps, and at their request I am sending six libraries of poetry, chosen by myself, and if these are successful and they want more, I stand ready to supply them. Of course there has been much poetry already given to the soldiers, but they still want more, and by choosing the libraries myself, I can give them what I think they ought to have, peptonizing it with a judicious mixture of what they probably want. Of course I am including “Images” and “Sea Garden” in all these libraries.

Do not let your spirits go down, and do not think that because you are not writing at the moment it means anything for the future. I am quite certain that when the war is over and you get back to civil life, you will find that the experience has done you good, and the contact with rough, real life and simple, elementary men has been an advantage rather than a disadvantage. Of course you may say it is all very well for me to talk this way who am not in it, and perhaps that is true, but still I think if I had the health, I could stand the rest of it. However, that is only conjecture, and perhaps I could not. Never mind.

Your account of your life is exactly what I wanted, only I should like a little account of your entering the army, and your rise from private to officer. I know this is immaterial to you, but I think it shows your character, and, as you can see from “Tendencies,” I like every little thing that tends to illustrate the character of my poets.

I do not wonder you feel grateful to Ezra Pound. In spite of his having treated me very badly, I feel grateful to him too, and he is now writing me conciliatory letters. I wish I did not know that he thinks I have made a success and does not want to be on bad terms with me. However, that is Ezra all over, and I have answered him shortly and pleasantly. I will not publish in “The Little Review,” which is given over to him and his satellites, but I bear him no ill will, and I think he has written fine poetry – very fine poetry. My objection to his work is that it is simply derivative. I do not think the man has an original thought or an original characteristic, but he is extraordinarily skillful in adopting the characteristics of a remote past, and when people do not know the past very well, this passes for originality. He has played his cards so badly that he is little better than a failure, which is unjust to him. But if only plays poetry like politics, one must expect to be treated like a politician. I do not believe people succeed, in the long run, who do not take poetry as religion.
There is a great deal of interest in your work over here, and it is considered very highly. I shall undoubtedly take these lectures and make certain chapters of a new book later on.

“Tendencies” is doing very well, and seems to be having quite an influence. You will see with amusement how much afraid of this influence Harriet Monroe is, and how she fears that her own judgments will go to the wall in face of mine. I have seldom read anything more shivering with fear than her review of the book in December “Poetry.”

I cannot escape the war now; I must write about it. It seems to be all round us, and I must say I think the few poems of yours which I have seen, dealing with the war, are excellent. Do not despise the war as a theme for poetry; do not despise any fact of life in that connection. Poetry should be the great underlying substance of every poet’s life, and none of his experiences can be alien to it when seen through his eyes. I am afraid this sounds a little didactic. That is the worst of the war. It brings one down to one’s bottom, and when one talks about the bottom, one always sounds goody-goody. Anyhow, I mean it.

closer.p: With lots of love and thanks for your good letter,

div.note: Harriet Monroe, "Miss Lowell on Tendencies," Poetry, Vol. 11, No. 3 (December, 1917), pp. 151-156.
